bestBHT.bht: Jesus fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah by withdrawing from the crowds, revealing the glory of his divinity through his humble human form. This demonstration served as a significant proof of his identity as the chosen Messiah, a fact acknowledged even by the Jewish community. Those who were offended by his lowly condition were unworthy of salvation. By fulfilling this prophecy, Jesus exemplified the truth of his divine mission, showcasing the perfect alignment between prophecy and his actions.

Henry Alford: On that it might be fulfilled, see note on ch. i. 22.
It must not be understood ‘and thus was fulfilled:’ it is used only of the purpose, not of the result, here or any where.
The prophecy is partly from the LXX, partly an original translation. The LXX have ‘Jacob my servant... Israel my chosen...,’ but the Rabbis generally understood it of the Messiah.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: 17. That it might be fulfilled which
was spoken by Esaias the prophet, saying— ( :-).
John Calvin: It was, therefore, no ordinary proof, how widely he was removed from the pomp and ostentation of the world.
By this circumstance he intended to show, that the glory of Christ’s divinity ought not to be the less admired, because it appeared under a vail of infirmity.
He who is offended by the low condition of Christ, which God declares to be agreeable to his will, is unworthy of salvation.
Philip Schaff: That it might be fulfilled, etc. While Mark details the occurrences, Matthew only declares that the retirement of our Lord was a fulfilment of prophecy, however contrary to the popular notions about the Messiah.
A translation from the Hebrew, made by the Evangelist.
Archibald T. Robertson: That it might be fulfilled (ινα πληρωθη). The final use of ινα and the sub-final just before (verse Matthew 12:16).
The passage quoted is Isaiah 42:1-4 'a very free reproduction of the Hebrew with occasional side glances at the Septuagint' (Bruce), possibly from an Aramaic collection of Testimonia (McNeile).
Matthew applies the prophecy about Cyrus to Christ.
John Gill: What was now done by Christ... was a fulfilling of this prophecy; in which the Holy Spirit foreknowing the disposition and actions of Christ, predicted them: which, when considered, must be looked upon as a very large proof of the truth of his being the Messiah.
For that this prophecy belongs to the Messiah, is owned by the Jews themselves.
This is an observation of the evangelist, that what was now done by Christ... was a fulfilling of this prophecy.

bhtAttempts.bht: In Matthew 12:17, it is stated that Jesus fulfilled the prophecy spoken by Isaiah the prophet. The purpose of this fulfillment is emphasized, as the prophecy served to demonstrate that Jesus was the chosen Messiah. By withdrawing from the crowds and not seeking worldly pomp and ostentation, Jesus revealed the glory of his divinity shining through the veil of his human form. Those who were offended by his humble condition were deemed unworthy of salvation. This fulfillment of prophecy is a significant proof of Jesus' identity as the Messiah, a fact acknowledged even by the Jews themselves.

In fulfillment of prophecy, Jesus withdrew from the crowds, emphasizing the purpose behind his actions. By avoiding worldly pomp, he revealed the glory of his divinity within his humble human form. Those who were offended by his lowly condition were deemed unworthy of salvation. This demonstration of prophecy fulfilled not only serves as a powerful affirmation of Jesus' identity as the Messiah, but it is also recognized by the Jews themselves as a testament to his divine mission.

Jesus fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah by withdrawing from the crowds and not seeking worldly pomp or ostentation, which demonstrated the glory of his divinity hidden beneath his human form. Those offended by his humble condition were deemed unworthy of salvation. This fulfillment is a significant proof of Jesus' identity as the Messiah, acknowledged even by the Jews themselves.

Jesus fulfilled the prophecy spoken by Isaiah, serving as proof of his identity as the Messiah. By withdrawing from the crowds and avoiding worldly pomp, Jesus revealed the glory of his divinity shining through his humble human form. Those who were offended by his lowly condition were unworthy of salvation. This fulfillment was a significant demonstration that validated Jesus' role as the chosen Messiah, a fact recognized even by the Jewish community.

Jesus fulfilled the prophecy of Isaiah by withdrawing from the crowds, revealing the glory of his divinity through his humble human form. This demonstration served as a significant proof of his identity as the chosen Messiah, a fact acknowledged even by the Jewish community. Those who were offended by his lowly condition were unworthy of salvation. By fulfilling this prophecy, Jesus exemplified the truth of his divine mission, showcasing the perfect alignment between prophecy and his actions.
